text: 6-Mute English from BBCLearningEnglish.com
Hello, this is 6-minute English from BBC Learning English. I'm Pippa.
And I’m Neil.
speaker: Neil

text: Now, Neil, have you ever wanted to be a musician?
speaker: Pippa

text: Oh yes, Pippa, I still want to be a musician. I've been playing my guitar since I was 14.
speaker: Neil

text: I've been playing my guitar since I was 14.
Wow. Well, maybe one day you'll manage it.
What about you?
speaker: Neil

text: I don't think I'd like to be a musician.
I think it would be a bit stressful, especially if you had lots of fans and more really successful.
Hmm, yeah. I wonder what life as a musician is actually like.
We'll be finding that out in this programme as we hear from some people around the UK
who would like to become successful musicians.
And we'll even listen to some of their music too.
But first, I have a question for you, Neil.
speaker: Pippa

text: In the UK, we have a weekly chart of the best selling songs in the country.
And the top selling song is called the number one.
But which musical artist do you think has had the most UK number one songs?
Is it A, the Beatles, B, Ed Sheeran or C, Elvis Presley?
Oh well, I think that's easy. It must be, surely, The Beatles.
speaker: Neil

text: Well, I’ll reveal the answer at the end of the programme.
speaker: Pippa

text: Now, getting a number one song is a dream for many musicians. But if you want to become a musician, where do you start?
speaker: Pippa

text: But if you want to become a musician, where do you start?
I grew up in a really rich music scene in St Ives.
I was going to open mics from the age of about 11.
This is Bailey. She lives in St Ives in Cornwall on the southwest coast of England.
She says she was going to open mic nights from a young age.
Open mic nights are events where anyone can sing or play music.
Bailey talked about her life as a musician to BBC Learning English programme My Song, My Home.
speaker: Pippa

text: I would go to these songwriter circles at the Ketlenwink on a Friday night after school,
where I'd be the youngest person by like 50 years,
but I'd sit in a circle of a bunch of old men,
and they'd play James Taylor and Carol King and the Eagles,
and lots of 70s music, and I guess that's influenced me massively.
But I guess, you know, everyone kind of took me under the wing growing up.
When she was younger, Bailey went to songwriter circles.
When she was younger, Bailey went to songwriters' circles. These are meetings for people interested in writing their own music.
speaker: songwriters' circles

text: Bailey remembers sitting with a bunch of old men.
Bailey remembers sitting with a bunch of old men. A bunch is an informal way to talk about a group of people.
speaker: bunchbunch

text: The older men in the group would play music from the 1970s,
and Bailey says they took her under their wing.
If you take somebody under your wing, you decide to protect them or guide them.
Let’s meet another musician, Josh.
speaker: Pippa

text: So I learnt my first proper song on guitar when I was about 13.
I literally started busking the moment I could kind of do that.
Josh lives in London and is a busker.
Josh lives in London and is a busker. This means that he performs on the street or in public places to earn money.
speaker: busker

text: Busking is a common way for musicians to make money and perform to more people,
and as Josh told BBC Learning English programme, my song, my home,
it can help musicians to get new opportunities.
It's been kind of like my main earner.
This kept me going for the last ten or so years.
From that it's then got me various different opportunities.
It's got me all my gigs, got me all my connections.
So I owe a lot to the busking.
Busking is Josh's main earner.
It's his main source of money.
He says that busking has got him all his gigs and connections. Gigs are musical concerts. It’s an informal, slang word.
speaker: buskinggigsGigs

text: Gigs are musical concerts and it's an informal slang word.
Josh says he owes a lot to busking.
If you owe a lot to someone or something, you have success or happiness because of that personal thing.
So, would you like to listen to some of Josh’s music, Neil?
speaker: owes a lot toowe a lot

text: Of course I would.
speaker: Neil

text: Well, here's a bit of his song, That Side of the Wall,
Well, here’s a bit of his song That Side of the Wall, which he performed for BBC Learning English programme My Song, My Home.
speaker: Pippa

text: Wow. Josh is pretty good, isn't he?. I’d love to hear more.
speaker: Neil

text: I'd love to hear more.
Well you can find performances by the musicians in the series on our website – bbclearningenglish.com. We’ll also put a link in the notes below this episode!
speaker: Pippa

text: BBCLearningEnglish.com, and we'll also put a link in the notes below this episode.
OK, so what about your question, Pipper?
Yes, I asked which artist had the most number one songs in the UK charts? The Beatles, Ed Sheeran or Elvis Presley?
speaker: Pippa

text: The Beatles, Ed Sheeran or Elvis?
And you said the Beatles, Neil.
But the answer is actually Elvis Presley.
He's had 21 number one songs and the Beatles have had 18.
Really? Well that's OK, I love 'the King' as well.
speaker: Neil

text: OK, let's recap the vocabulary we've learned in this musical episode,
OK, let’s recap the vocabulary we’ve learned in this musical episode, starting with open mic nights, events where anyone can sing or play music.
speaker: open mic nights

text: Songwriter circles, you can find a lot of different things in the series.
Songwriter circles are meetings for people interested in writing their own music.
A bunch of people is a group of people.
speaker: bunch

text: The expression takes someone under your wing, means to protect or guide someone.
Basking is performing in a public place for money, and a busker is someone who performs on the street for money.
Your main earner is your main source of income.
speaker: main earner

text: Gigs are musical concerts.
speaker: Gigs

text: And the expression to owe a lot to someone or something, means to have success or happiness because of that personal thing.
Once again, our six minutes are up that you can find my song, My Home, on our website,
BBCLearningEnglish.com.
Watch the songs and sing along and learn more about the vocabulary in the lyrics.
We’ll see you again soon for some more trending topics and useful vocabulary. Bye for now!
speaker: Pippa

text: Bye for now.
Goodbye!
speaker: Neil
